trans-unit.source: Try Azure App Service with Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Try Azure App Service with Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Try Azure Search for free, up to one hour, using the TryAzureAppService template.
trans-unit.target: Try Azure Search for free, up to one hour, using the TryAzureAppService template.

trans-unit.source: Try Azure App Service with Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Try Azure App Service with Azure Search

trans-unit.source: [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) is a new, entirely free way to test-drive selected Azure Services, including Azure Search, for up to one hour with no Azure subscription sign-up required.
trans-unit.target: [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) is a new, entirely free way to test-drive selected Azure Services, including Azure Search, for up to one hour with no Azure subscription sign-up required.

trans-unit.source: The site gives you several templates to choose from.
trans-unit.target: The site gives you several templates to choose from.

trans-unit.source: When you select the ASP.NET template that includes Azure Search, you gain one hour of access to a fully functional web site, backed by the services you selected.
trans-unit.target: When you select the ASP.NET template that includes Azure Search, you gain one hour of access to a fully functional web site, backed by the services you selected.

trans-unit.source: You won't be able to update or delete any of the data managed by Azure Search – but you can execute queries and make any number of code changes that reshapes the user experience.
trans-unit.target: You won't be able to update or delete any of the data managed by Azure Search – but you can execute queries and make any number of code changes that reshapes the user experience.

trans-unit.source: If the session expires before you’re done exploring, you can always start over with another session, or move on to a trial or full subscription if your goal is to create or load an index directly.
trans-unit.target: If the session expires before you’re done exploring, you can always start over with another session, or move on to a trial or full subscription if your goal is to create or load an index directly.

trans-unit.source: On the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) site, Azure Search is part of the Web App template – providing a rich, full-text search experience along with a slew of search-centric features available only in this service on the Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: On the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) site, Azure Search is part of the Web App template – providing a rich, full-text search experience along with a slew of search-centric features available only in this service on the Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: Although other Azure services such as SQL Database offer full-text search, a service like Azure Search gives you tuning control, pagination and counts, hit highlighting, auto-complete query suggestions, natural language support, faceted navigation, filtering and more.
trans-unit.target: Although other Azure services such as SQL Database offer full-text search, a service like Azure Search gives you tuning control, pagination and counts, hit highlighting, auto-complete query suggestions, natural language support, faceted navigation, filtering and more.

trans-unit.source: As several of our [samples](https://github.com/AzureSearch) demonstrate, it’s possible to develop a full-featured search-based application using just Azure Search and ASP.NET.
trans-unit.target: As several of our [samples](https://github.com/AzureSearch) demonstrate, it’s possible to develop a full-featured search-based application using just Azure Search and ASP.NET.

trans-unit.source: As part of the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) offering, the Azure Search service you’ll use is read-only – which means you will need to use the search corpus provided in the session.
trans-unit.target: As part of the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) offering, the Azure Search service you’ll use is read-only – which means you will need to use the search corpus provided in the session.

trans-unit.source: You cannot upload or use your own index or data.
trans-unit.target: You cannot upload or use your own index or data.

trans-unit.source: The data you’ll work with is from the [United States Geological Survey (USGS)](), consisting of about 3 million rows of landmarks, historical sites, buildings, and other landmark features across the US.
trans-unit.target: The data you’ll work with is from the [United States Geological Survey (USGS)](), consisting of about 3 million rows of landmarks, historical sites, buildings, and other landmark features across the US.

trans-unit.source: To help you get the most out of your one hour session, the following instructions will walk you through queries and code.
trans-unit.target: To help you get the most out of your one hour session, the following instructions will walk you through queries and code.

trans-unit.source: Before moving ahead, you might want to take a few minutes review a few key points about the code, service, and searchable data.
trans-unit.target: Before moving ahead, you might want to take a few minutes review a few key points about the code, service, and searchable data.

trans-unit.source: Having a little background could prove useful if you’re not already familiar with Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: Having a little background could prove useful if you’re not already familiar with Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: Facts about the code and Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Facts about the code and Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Azure Search is a service-plus-data [PaaS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platform_as_a_service) offering, consisting of a fully managed search service, plus searchable data that you upload when using an unconstrained instance of Azure Search (i.e., when you are not using the Try Azure App Service option).
trans-unit.target: Azure Search is a service-plus-data [PaaS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Platform_as_a_service) offering, consisting of a fully managed search service, plus searchable data that you upload when using an unconstrained instance of Azure Search (i.e., when you are not using the Try Azure App Service option).

trans-unit.source: Data used in search operations is stored with your search service in Azure, where proximity of data to operations ensures low latency and consistent search behaviors.
trans-unit.target: Data used in search operations is stored with your search service in Azure, where proximity of data to operations ensures low latency and consistent search behaviors.

trans-unit.source: There is currently no support for offline or remote storage of searchable data.
trans-unit.target: There is currently no support for offline or remote storage of searchable data.

trans-unit.source: Drilling into this a bit further:
trans-unit.target: Drilling into this a bit further:

trans-unit.source: Search data is stored in an index managed by Azure Search, populated by documents, one document per searchable item.
trans-unit.target: Search data is stored in an index managed by Azure Search, populated by documents, one document per searchable item.

trans-unit.source: Most indexes are loaded from a single dataset, prepared in advance by you to include only those fields that are useful in the context of search operations.
trans-unit.target: Most indexes are loaded from a single dataset, prepared in advance by you to include only those fields that are useful in the context of search operations.

trans-unit.source: The schema that defines your index is user-defined and will specify searchable fields, non-searchable fields that could be useful in a filter expression, and constructs like scoring profiles for tuning results.
trans-unit.target: The schema that defines your index is user-defined and will specify searchable fields, non-searchable fields that could be useful in a filter expression, and constructs like scoring profiles for tuning results.

trans-unit.source: Data can be auto-loaded by an Indexer (supported for Azure SQL Database or Azure DocumentDB only), or pushed to a search index via one of the Azure Search APIs.
trans-unit.target: Data can be auto-loaded by an Indexer (supported for Azure SQL Database or Azure DocumentDB only), or pushed to a search index via one of the Azure Search APIs.

trans-unit.source: When you use the API, you can push data from any data source, as long as it’s in JSON format.
trans-unit.target: When you use the API, you can push data from any data source, as long as it’s in JSON format.

trans-unit.source: In the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) option, the ASP.NET + Azure Search Site template provides source code for the Web application, modifiable in Visual Studio Online (available as a part of the one-hour session).
trans-unit.target: In the [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) option, the ASP.NET + Azure Search Site template provides source code for the Web application, modifiable in Visual Studio Online (available as a part of the one-hour session).

trans-unit.source: No separate development tools are required to view or change the code.
trans-unit.target: No separate development tools are required to view or change the code.

trans-unit.source: Code is written in C#, using the [Azure Search .NET client library](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn951165.aspx) to execute queries against the index, provide faceted navigation, and display counts and search results in a web page.
trans-unit.target: Code is written in C#, using the [Azure Search .NET client library](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn951165.aspx) to execute queries against the index, provide faceted navigation, and display counts and search results in a web page.

trans-unit.source: Other code, not included in the template, was used to build and load the USGS search index.
trans-unit.target: Other code, not included in the template, was used to build and load the USGS search index.

trans-unit.source: Because the service is read-only, all operations requiring write-access had to be completed in advance.
trans-unit.target: Because the service is read-only, all operations requiring write-access had to be completed in advance.

trans-unit.source: You can see a [copy of the schema](#schema) used to build the schema at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: You can see a [copy of the schema](#schema) used to build the schema at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: Get started
trans-unit.target: Get started

trans-unit.source: If you haven’t started your 1-hour session yet, follow these steps to get started.
trans-unit.target: If you haven’t started your 1-hour session yet, follow these steps to get started.

trans-unit.source: Go to [https://tryappservice.azure.com](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) and scroll down to select **Web App**.
trans-unit.target: Go to [https://tryappservice.azure.com](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) and scroll down to select **Web App**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next**.

trans-unit.source: Choose the **ASP.NET + Azure Search Site** template.
trans-unit.target: Choose the **ASP.NET + Azure Search Site** template.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Choose a login method and provide the username and password.
trans-unit.target: Choose a login method and provide the username and password.

trans-unit.source: Wait while the site is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: Wait while the site is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: When it’s ready, you will see a page similar to this one.
trans-unit.target: When it’s ready, you will see a page similar to this one.

trans-unit.source: Each page shows a running clock so that you always know how much time you have left.
trans-unit.target: Each page shows a running clock so that you always know how much time you have left.

trans-unit.source: Choose **Edit with Visual Studio Online** to view the solution and browse the site.
trans-unit.target: Choose **Edit with Visual Studio Online** to view the solution and browse the site.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio Online, expand the session options at the top of the page, and then click **Browse Web Site**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio Online, expand the session options at the top of the page, and then click **Browse Web Site**.

trans-unit.source: You should see the getting started page for your Azure Search web site.
trans-unit.target: You should see the getting started page for your Azure Search web site.

trans-unit.source: Click the **Get Started** button to open the site.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Get Started** button to open the site.

trans-unit.source: An ASP.NET web site opens in the browser, providing a search box.
trans-unit.target: An ASP.NET web site opens in the browser, providing a search box.

trans-unit.source: Enter a familiar term to search on, such as *Yellowstone* or a well-known mountain like *Mount Rainier*.
trans-unit.target: Enter a familiar term to search on, such as *Yellowstone* or a well-known mountain like *Mount Rainier*.

trans-unit.source: Starting with a familiar landmark makes it easier to evaluate the results.
trans-unit.target: Starting with a familiar landmark makes it easier to evaluate the results.

trans-unit.source: What to do first
trans-unit.target: What to do first

trans-unit.source: Since the search index is fully operational, a good first step is to try out a few queries.
trans-unit.target: Since the search index is fully operational, a good first step is to try out a few queries.

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Search supports all of the standard search operators (+, -, |), quotation marks for literal matches, wildcard (*), and precedence operators.
trans-unit.target: Search supports all of the standard search operators (+, -, |), quotation marks for literal matches, wildcard (*), and precedence operators.

trans-unit.source: You can review the query syntax reference for the full list of operators.
trans-unit.target: You can review the query syntax reference for the full list of operators.

trans-unit.source: Start with a wildcard search by adding an asterisk (`*`).
trans-unit.target: Start with a wildcard search by adding an asterisk (`*`).

trans-unit.source: This tells you how many documents are found in the index: 2,262,578.
trans-unit.target: This tells you how many documents are found in the index: 2,262,578.

trans-unit.source: Next, enter "Yellowstone", then add "+center", "+building", and "-ND" to progressively narrow search results to just the Yellowstone visitor centers, excluding those in North Dakota: `Yellowstone +center +building -ND`.
trans-unit.target: Next, enter "Yellowstone", then add "+center", "+building", and "-ND" to progressively narrow search results to just the Yellowstone visitor centers, excluding those in North Dakota: `Yellowstone +center +building -ND`.

trans-unit.source: Try a search phrase that combines precedence operators and string matching: `statue+(park+MT)`.
trans-unit.target: Try a search phrase that combines precedence operators and string matching: `statue+(park+MT)`.

trans-unit.source: You should see results similar to the screenshot below.
trans-unit.target: You should see results similar to the screenshot below.

trans-unit.source: Notice that facet categories appear under Feature Class, offering self-directed filtering through faceted navigation, a feature commonly found in most search applications.
trans-unit.target: Notice that facet categories appear under Feature Class, offering self-directed filtering through faceted navigation, a feature commonly found in most search applications.

trans-unit.source: Ready to move on?
trans-unit.target: Ready to move on?

trans-unit.source: Let’s change a few lines of code to see the impact on full-text search operations.
trans-unit.target: Let’s change a few lines of code to see the impact on full-text search operations.

trans-unit.source: Change searchMode.All
trans-unit.target: Change searchMode.All

trans-unit.source: Azure Search has a configurable **searchMode** property that you can use to control search operator behavior.
trans-unit.target: Azure Search has a configurable **searchMode** property that you can use to control search operator behavior.

trans-unit.source: Valid values for this property are `Any` (default) or `All`.
trans-unit.target: Valid values for this property are `Any` (default) or `All`.

trans-unit.source: See [Simple Query Syntax](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn798920.aspx) for more guidance on setting these options.
trans-unit.target: See [Simple Query Syntax](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn798920.aspx) for more guidance on setting these options.

trans-unit.source: **searchMode.Any** stipulates that any match on a search term is sufficient to include an item in the search results.
trans-unit.target: **searchMode.Any** stipulates that any match on a search term is sufficient to include an item in the search results.

trans-unit.source: If your search phrase is `Yellowstone visitor center`, then any document containing any of these terms is included in the search results.
trans-unit.target: If your search phrase is `Yellowstone visitor center`, then any document containing any of these terms is included in the search results.

trans-unit.source: This mode is biased towards *recall*.
trans-unit.target: This mode is biased towards *recall*.

trans-unit.source: **searchModel.All**, used in this sample, requires that all of the specified terms be present in the document.
trans-unit.target: **searchModel.All**, used in this sample, requires that all of the specified terms be present in the document.

trans-unit.source: This mode is more stringent than **searchMode.Any**, but if you favor *precision* over recall, it is probably the right choice for your application.
trans-unit.target: This mode is more stringent than **searchMode.Any**, but if you favor *precision* over recall, it is probably the right choice for your application.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] **searchMode.Any** works best when query construction consists mostly of phrases, with minimal use of operators.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] **searchMode.Any** works best when query construction consists mostly of phrases, with minimal use of operators.

trans-unit.source: A general rule of thumb is that people searching consumer applications, such as e-commerce sites, tend to use just terms, whereas people searching on content or data are more likely to include operators in the search phrase.
trans-unit.target: A general rule of thumb is that people searching consumer applications, such as e-commerce sites, tend to use just terms, whereas people searching on content or data are more likely to include operators in the search phrase.

trans-unit.source: If you believe searches are likely to include operators, particularly the `NOT (-)` operator, start with **searchModel.All**.
trans-unit.target: If you believe searches are likely to include operators, particularly the `NOT (-)` operator, start with **searchModel.All**.

trans-unit.source: In contrast, your other choice, **searchMode.Any** will `OR` the `NOT` operator with other search terms, which can dramatically expand rather than trim results.
trans-unit.target: In contrast, your other choice, **searchMode.Any** will `OR` the `NOT` operator with other search terms, which can dramatically expand rather than trim results.

trans-unit.source: The example below can help you understand the difference.
trans-unit.target: The example below can help you understand the difference.

trans-unit.source: In this task, you will change the **searchMode** and compare search outcomes based on mode.
trans-unit.target: In this task, you will change the **searchMode** and compare search outcomes based on mode.

trans-unit.source: Open the browser window containing the sample application, choose **Connect to Visual Studio Online**.
trans-unit.target: Open the browser window containing the sample application, choose **Connect to Visual Studio Online**.

trans-unit.source: Open **Search.cshtml**, find `searchMode.All` on line 39 and change it to `searchMode.Any`.
trans-unit.target: Open **Search.cshtml**, find `searchMode.All` on line 39 and change it to `searchMode.Any`.

trans-unit.source: In the jump bar to the right, click **Run**.
trans-unit.target: In the jump bar to the right, click **Run**.

trans-unit.source: In the rebuilt application window, enter a search term that you’ve used before, such as `Yellowstone +center +building -ND`, and compare the before-and-after results of changes to **searchMode**.
trans-unit.target: In the rebuilt application window, enter a search term that you’ve used before, such as `Yellowstone +center +building -ND`, and compare the before-and-after results of changes to **searchMode**.

trans-unit.source: It’s a pretty big difference.
trans-unit.target: It’s a pretty big difference.

trans-unit.source: Instead of seven search results, you get over two million.
trans-unit.target: Instead of seven search results, you get over two million.

trans-unit.source: The behavior you’re observing is due to the inclusion `NOT` operator (in this case, "-ND"), which is *OR'd* rather than *AND'd* when **searchMode** is set to `Any`.
trans-unit.target: The behavior you’re observing is due to the inclusion `NOT` operator (in this case, "-ND"), which is *OR'd* rather than *AND'd* when **searchMode** is set to `Any`.

trans-unit.source: Given this configuration, the search results include hits for the search terms `Yellowstone`, `center`, and `building`, but also every document that is `NOT North Dakota`.
trans-unit.target: Given this configuration, the search results include hits for the search terms `Yellowstone`, `center`, and `building`, but also every document that is `NOT North Dakota`.

trans-unit.source: Since there are only 13,081 documents containing the phrase `North Dakota`, almost all of the dataset is returned.
trans-unit.target: Since there are only 13,081 documents containing the phrase `North Dakota`, almost all of the dataset is returned.

trans-unit.source: Admittedly, this is perhaps an unlikely scenario, but it illustrates the effects of **searchMode** on search phrases that include the `NOT` operator, so it’s useful to understand why the behavior occurs and how to change it if this is not what you want.
trans-unit.target: Admittedly, this is perhaps an unlikely scenario, but it illustrates the effects of **searchMode** on search phrases that include the `NOT` operator, so it’s useful to understand why the behavior occurs and how to change it if this is not what you want.

trans-unit.source: To continue with this tutorial, revert **searchMode** back to its original value (set to `All` on line 39), run the program, and use the rebuilt app for the remaining tasks.
trans-unit.target: To continue with this tutorial, revert **searchMode** back to its original value (set to `All` on line 39), run the program, and use the rebuilt app for the remaining tasks.

trans-unit.source: Add a global filter for Washington State
trans-unit.target: Add a global filter for Washington State

trans-unit.source: Normally, if you wanted to search over a subset of available data, you would set the filter at the data source when importing data.
trans-unit.target: Normally, if you wanted to search over a subset of available data, you would set the filter at the data source when importing data.

trans-unit.source: For learning purposes, working with read-only data, we’ll set the filter in our application to return just the documents that include Washington State.
trans-unit.target: For learning purposes, working with read-only data, we’ll set the filter in our application to return just the documents that include Washington State.

trans-unit.source: Open Search.cshtml, find the **SearchParameters** code block (starting on line 36) and add a comment line plus filter.
trans-unit.target: Open Search.cshtml, find the **SearchParameters** code block (starting on line 36) and add a comment line plus filter.

trans-unit.source: Filters are specified using OData syntax and are frequently used with faceted navigation or included in the query string to constrain the query.
trans-unit.target: Filters are specified using OData syntax and are frequently used with faceted navigation or included in the query string to constrain the query.

trans-unit.source: See [OData Filter Syntax](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn798921.aspx) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [OData Filter Syntax](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn798921.aspx) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Click **Run**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Run**.

trans-unit.source: Open the application.
trans-unit.target: Open the application.

trans-unit.source: Type the wildcard (*) to return a count.
trans-unit.target: Type the wildcard (*) to return a count.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the results are now limited to 42,411 items, which are all of the documents for all of the geographical features in Washington State.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the results are now limited to 42,411 items, which are all of the documents for all of the geographical features in Washington State.

trans-unit.source: Add Hit Highlighting
trans-unit.target: Add Hit Highlighting

trans-unit.source: Now that you have made a series of one-line code changes, you might want to try deeper modifications that require code changes in multiple places.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have made a series of one-line code changes, you might want to try deeper modifications that require code changes in multiple places.

trans-unit.source: The following version of **Search.cshtml** can be pasted right over the Search.cshtml file in your current session.
trans-unit.target: The following version of **Search.cshtml** can be pasted right over the Search.cshtml file in your current session.

trans-unit.source: The following code adds hit-highlighting.
trans-unit.target: The following code adds hit-highlighting.

trans-unit.source: Notice the new properties declared in the [SearchParameters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.search.models.searchparameters_properties.aspx).
trans-unit.target: Notice the new properties declared in the [SearchParameters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/microsoft.azure.search.models.searchparameters_properties.aspx).

trans-unit.source: There is also a new function that iterates over the collection of results to get the documents that need highlighting, plus HTML that renders the result.
trans-unit.target: There is also a new function that iterates over the collection of results to get the documents that need highlighting, plus HTML that renders the result.

trans-unit.source: When you run this code sample, search term inputs that have a corresponding match in specified fields are highlighted in bold font.
trans-unit.target: When you run this code sample, search term inputs that have a corresponding match in specified fields are highlighted in bold font.

trans-unit.source: You might want to save a copy of the original **Search.cshtml** file to see how both versions compare.
trans-unit.target: You might want to save a copy of the original **Search.cshtml** file to see how both versions compare.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Comments have been trimmed to reduce the size of the file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Comments have been trimmed to reduce the size of the file.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Using the read-only service provided in [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) site, you have seen the query syntax and full-text search in action, learned about searchMode and filters, and added hit-highlighting to your search application.
trans-unit.target: Using the read-only service provided in [Try Azure App Service](https://tryappservice.azure.com/) site, you have seen the query syntax and full-text search in action, learned about searchMode and filters, and added hit-highlighting to your search application.

trans-unit.source: As your next step, consider moving on to creating and updating indexes.
trans-unit.target: As your next step, consider moving on to creating and updating indexes.

trans-unit.source: This adds the ability to:
trans-unit.target: This adds the ability to:

trans-unit.source: [Define scoring profiles](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn798928.aspx) used for tuning search scores so that high-value items show up first.
trans-unit.target: [Define scoring profiles](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn798928.aspx) used for tuning search scores so that high-value items show up first.

trans-unit.source: [Define Suggesters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt131377.aspx) that add auto-complete or type-ahead query suggestions in response to user input.
trans-unit.target: [Define Suggesters](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/mt131377.aspx) that add auto-complete or type-ahead query suggestions in response to user input.

trans-unit.source: [Define indexers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn946891.aspx) that update your index automatically whenever the data source is Azure SQL Database or Azure DocumentDB.
trans-unit.target: [Define indexers](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn946891.aspx) that update your index automatically whenever the data source is Azure SQL Database or Azure DocumentDB.

trans-unit.source: To perform all these tasks, you’ll need an Azure subscription so that you can create and populate indexes in a service.
trans-unit.target: To perform all these tasks, you’ll need an Azure subscription so that you can create and populate indexes in a service.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to sign up for a free trial, visit [https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to sign up for a free trial, visit [https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial](https://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Azure Search, visit our [documentation page](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/search/) on [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com) or check out any number of [samples and videos](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn818681.aspx) that explore the full range of Azure Search functionality.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure Search, visit our [documentation page](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/services/search/) on [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com) or check out any number of [samples and videos](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/dn818681.aspx) that explore the full range of Azure Search functionality.

trans-unit.source: About the schema
trans-unit.target: About the schema

trans-unit.source: The following screenshot shows the schema used to create the index used in this template.
trans-unit.target: The following screenshot shows the schema used to create the index used in this template.

trans-unit.source: Schema.json file
trans-unit.target: Schema.json file
